The yellow crazy ant is a medium-sized ant, typically measuring between 4-6 millimeters in length. Its body is yellowish-brown in color, with a reddish-brown head and gaster (abdomen). The species is characterized by its long, thin legs, which can be up to twice the length of its body, and its ability to move in a frenetic, unpredictable manner, often appearing to "dance" as it forages.

Anoplolepis gracilipes is an invasive species that has been introduced to various parts of the world, including the Pacific Islands, Indian Ocean islands, and parts of Australia and Africa. It is considered a pest due to its ability to outcompete and displace native ant species, as well as its potential to cause ecological and economic damage in the areas it invades.

The yellow crazy ant is known to be an opportunistic omnivore, feeding on a wide range of resources, including insects, honeydew, and various plant materials. It is also known to form mutualistic relationships with sap-feeding insects, such as aphids and scale insects, which can further contribute to its invasive success.

Understanding the biology, ecology, and management of the yellow crazy ant is an important area of research, particularly in regions where it has been introduced and poses a threat to native ecosystems.
